comments.commentBody: The  brain is a funny thing...at least mine is.  It can miraculously dredge up answers buried deep within the gray matter, obscure facts that I didn't even know I knew, and yet can't find the energy to get from GO MOO to GO PRO.  Go figure.

This was my all-time most satisfying acrostic, because this time, I didn't know a single answer off-hand.  The second time through, I guessed "offshoot".  I almost didn't even try, but gradually, then more suddenly, things became clear and I got it at the end.  I felt like my brain really had a workout.  I always like to figure out a percentage of how many letters I knew.  Anything under 15% makes me happy.  Today's was my lowest percentage ever!  Thanks so much for a very gratifying experience.  I do love acrostics!

Am I first? The Sunday puzzle arrives here at 1 a.m. and depending on what time I have to wake up (Sunday is a regular workday here) I often get right down to it before I go to sleep, which I just did, a quickie, 26 minutes (as fast as I could type) and found a certain pleasure in the rebus entries.  Good night, all.

I agree, Deb, the theme entries were clever and fun.  I've gotten so I don't like these choppy puzzles that have so many 3- and 4-letter words, but they seem to be pretty standard Sunday fare.  This one fell pretty quickly, too, in spite of a number of "random letter" entries like LEK, ETO, OPS, SFC, ULA, CGI and some pretty obscure names (KOKO, EDESSA, IVEYS, NAMU).  Missteps for me at SEATAC (started with Reagan) and TYPESIZE (started with Typeface).
A quick reply to your comment yesterday . My UK spellcheck automatically puts the U in favourite.  It just did it on my new iPad.

I thought initially that the keyword was NEW from the cross of DELIVER THE GOOD ? S and RE?, but thought better of it when OLDSTER showed up nearby.

One thing that surprises me about xwordinfo is that they don't seem to have statistics about freshness of rebus entries. Am I missing something there?

http://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/12/2012
Don't you hate those red triangles?  I also feel they signal my ignorance. Sometimes I think they flap in derision. :-)

"Green Onions" was the hit song by Booker T. And the MGs.
Some of us are old enough to remember it well!
Booker T & the MGs were a sould groups whose most famous hit was probably Green Onions. You can find a nice version of it on YouTube.
I believe SFC stands for Sergeant First Class.

Hmmm. No comments yet. I knew I was doing the puzzle too early, but I've got a bunch of work to do tomorrow.

I found it rather too easy, but still enjoyable because of some nice theme entries. I particularly liked MEET ONE'S BOOKMAKER and BOOKMARK MY WORDS. Unfortunately, the fact that it was a rebus became apparently almost instantly, at 10D.

I don't know SFC, nor am I familiar with this clue for BOOKER T. Also didn't get the clue for our old XW standby ELO.

On to the acrostic! (This is an acrostic week, right?)

It was kind of a trick clue.
I had to look up the defintion of the word, and I then put in BOUQUET, which turned out to be wrong.
Apparently "tussie-mussie" does (or did) have an independent existence... I've heard of it in relation to old Southern custom --- think cotillion

A lovely quote, and I'm sorry that apparently we won't be seeing an acrostic of the other, equally lovely, one.

On the coincidence front, I have been redoing some acrostics from long enough ago that they weren't front-of-mind (and were doable on the computer instead of paper), and just yesterday did one with "tussie mussie." Does this term really exist outside of acrostics? But today I proudly knew the answer!

Alas, I must confess I knew very little about ELIHU ROOT. I must see to improving my education.
DONKEY'S YEARS is an expression for "old".
John, DONKEY'S YEARS is a very old expression meaning 'forever and ever', as in 'He's been crotchety for donkey's years!'  (Burros seem to have a rep for longevity.)

Juan, I just Senor comment and I really appreciate the SUNXWDP mention, especially since I haven't already submitted any of my own.
Since it's generally known I'm not inclined to attempt solving Sunday offerings, it hasn't prevented me from commenting on them....hahahaha

Adios, my Chicano Chicago Amigo

Favorite was MEET ONE’S [BOOK]MAKER.

Least favorite was DONKEYS’ YEAR[BOOK]S because without BOOK we are left with DONKEYS’ YEARS instead of DONKEYS’ EARS.

Who knew OMBRE was a card game? I thought he was Señor Owie….

fascinating all
[ an aside: we used to live in New Vernon, 1980-1984 ]
I pick "folded linen"-- sweet!

APPLE PIE ORDER was new to me.  I like the variety of theories as to its etymology:  from the French "nappe plié" (“folded linen”), or from the French  "cap-à-pie" (“head to foot”),  or because of the way apple slices are arranged when making a pie, or as a corruption of "alpha, beta"  Take your pick, I guess.

Please tell me you have something more, Lieutenant.
I was expecting some kind of clever payoff, but nothing....no arrow, no cupid.
A weak heart. Two, and only two, poor theme answers. The church doesn't even celebrate it as "Saint" Valentine's Day.
Tenderheartedly was how grandma spoke, not a Valentine love message.
cleared lanes? what's next, squished frogs?
pluralized people names at 5D, 28A, 30A.
made up car names are bad enough, but to use them in The Puzzle?
La Scala, the name, has nothing to do a Staircase, but a family, the della Scalas.
Rhin, not rhino? Gimme a break.
a plethora of prepositions.
GO PRO was Saturday-worthy. Yay!
A Shortz shortcoming.

This is so true. I have lots government employee neighbors. We have deficits yet there are conferences to attend in Swizterland another one in Half Moon Bay, Ca. The hotel was the Ritz Carlton. But no can't cut the Fed budget without cutting essential services. The waste in the Fed government is astounding.

Her "troubles" weren't just iconic American. We haven't cornered the market on celebrities with problems of drugs and abusive family members.
Edith Piaf the incredible French singer whose life was portrayed in "La Vie en Rose" struggle with morphine addiction most of her life. She summed up her drug and alcohol addiction and resultant liver failure with the song: "Je Ne Regrettte Rien." "I regret nothing."
Natasha Collins and Filip Nikolic also come quickly to mind.
Every country has alcohol and drug addiction right down to entire Asian populations who chew betel nuts every day for its stimulant properties. The addiction causes the teeth to turn black.

She did the national anthem so well she upstaged the football game at the Super Bowl. That is All American. Many are good singers, a few are great, but nobody else has ever done that.

Her troubles were iconic American too. We all can feel for her.

I'll miss her.
Yes,  Eli Manning is New York's greatest quarterback.

Unfortunately, many people are confused by a depth of passion by a few very vocal people and mistake that for some sort of consensus of opinion.

In reality it is merely being unable to hear truth because of all of the shouting.

Science does not deal in "Truth", there is no such thing. Science merely states what the known evidence is and the best possible explanation for that evidence. When the evidence and the consequent conclusions change people often say that science was "Wrong". It wasn't wrong, it was still the best possible answer at the
time, given the evidence available.

Science is never wrong but it is also never right because it takes no opinion on "Truth". If you think that makes science worth less then you need to turn in the computer you are reading this on.

What is wrong is clinging to belief in the face of contrary evidence and that is the provence of religion.

Do not confuse anecdotes with causality.
How is it slave labour when they get paid and can leave the job whenever they want?
Perhaps, but so does RIM and any other consumer electronics manufacturer...

Apple uses what amounts to slave labor in China to assemble their products and  the greed at the top rejects an American workforce for manufacturing. Remember the 1984 commercial where Apple hated companies whose workers were nothing more than drones? Turns out they are no different.  Apple still sucks.

Nader has been saying for years that we need a second party. I voted for him because of that.

I wonder now if we have even one party. Really we just have a collection of egos, all self aggrandizing, offering nothing coherent for even one party. Hope? That was the best we got from one side, and anti du jour from the other. A narcissist every one of them, most egomaniacs.

Those are not parties. Not even one party.

The Republican party does have a policy! They are against contraceptives. In the back rooms, they are pondering whether to bring back witch burnings and excommunication for believing the earth circles the sun. When they get over screaming about religous freedom, they are welcome to join the rest of us in the 2st century

Hi Joao. You probably don't remember me, but I was one of those guys you went out on patrol with the day before you got blown up. I was back at our combat outpost when I heard the explosion. I just wanted to let you know that everyone was really impressed by how composed you were when you got blown up, and we're not an easy bunch to impress. Also, no other photographer had the guts to visit us after you were injured. Glad to hear you're doing well.

There is absolutely nothing irrational about the Catholic Church forbidding contraception to its believers. It's an integral part of the Church's survival strategy. In order to exert power every religion must set up the "guilt trap". Restrictions on sexual activity work best because sex is programmed into us. Lack of contraception results in large families and is a main source of human misery. So the Church creates the situation that increases the need for the Church's promises of spiritual rewards in another life after death. This approach does not work in Europe any more, people don' go to Church any more, and the Catholic Church has essentially given up on Europe. But it still works in Africa and Latin America. And look how much human suffering the prevention of contraception creates there. In terms of creation of human misery, I would rank the pope and bishops right at the top.

BTW, the "guilt trap" is also the reason why the Catholic Church won't budge on coelibacy of priests, but will tolerate children of priest out of wedlock and pay alimony for up to 3 children (I know - I grew up in a catholic family in Austria). And it will always cover for pedophile priests (in Austria even the Cardinal got caught with boys ...). Before the lawsuits in the US they were cheaper because no alimony needed to be paid ...

The views of the Bishops are irrational and based upon magical thinking and mythology. It is impossible to reason to reason with a person or an institution with a fanatic beliefs that are not amenable to reality testing.

If the issue was about taxing the rich more, the Bishops would have been on the side of Obama. Such is the nature of religion.
A religion whose identity revolves around serving the poor and vulnerable would then regarding contraception support a position that would harm women from that population solely on theological grounds.

Obama had no choice but to find a win/win solution because as anyone in crises management knows, it is difficult to use reality based arguments and engage in a debate with an individual who holds views they believe are sacrosanct whose violation would be in direct conflict a supernatural Being upon whom ones salvation depends.

This was no different that conducting a hostage negotiation with a person who was delusional. All the reasons Mr. Kristof cited in this column mean nothing to Bishop Dolan, because in his view it would violate God's law, transcends reality and reason.

He is choosing "God" over the health poor women. You can't use reason with such a person.

Organized religion will continue to clash with Modernity on issues such as these and will have to change or lose all relevance in the coming decades.

What we saw in this debate was the fact that so much religious thinking is based upon shared delusions

Great analysis here. What we've seen with Lin is truly historic. With his 4th start he now has more points made than any player since the ABA-NBA merger, topping Iverson, Shaq, Jordan, even. Now I can't say that he will have a career close to any of these players, he might turn out to be a mere footnote in the history of the NBA, but for a guy that literally was riding the bench, waived twice, almost waived a third time, sent to the D league four times, it's mind boggling.  I still can't believe what I've seen this past week. Nobody saw this coming... it's a great story.

I am so saddened to hear of Ms. Houston's untimely death. She is, in my opinion, the best female vocalist of my generation and her music serves as a big part of the soundtrack of my life, as I am sure it does for many others.

She was a true blue SINGER who didn't need any affectations or trills or overwrought theatrics to move her audience--she simply opened her mouth and sang. At her best she was incandescent and I'm heartbroken that she'll never have the chance to make the big comeback I was always convinced was just around the corner.

I remember when she was pregnant with her daughter...you could just see how happy she was and how much being a mother meant to her. I don't know when or how exactly things got off track for her and at this moment it doesn't matter. A mother has lost her daughter; a much-loved and wanted child has lost her mother, and the world has lost a brilliant talent.

My deepest sympathy goes to her family and friends.
Ummm: John Belushi.  His older brother Jim is still alive.
Reports of Jim Belushi's death are greatly exaggerated.

This is incredibly sad! Michael Jackson, Amy Winehouse, Jim Morrison, Jimi Hendrix, Jim Belushi, and on and on and on.

We look at these celebrities and try to imagine how wonderful their lives are!
So many people are such tortured souls...can anyone really understand the addictions these people have?...no different from a young single mom in poverty or a trust fund teenager in a Park Avenue high-rise who reaches out for drugs for its numbing effect.

Man's eternal quest to evade our own mortality. Religion, drugs (including alcohol), cigarettes, high risk behavior... And it only speeds that person towards the inevitable death. No one to blame. War on drugs will never be the answer. We have superior brains but cannot fathom our own minds, our own souls.

Oh Whitney!

Obama picked a fight?  Are you really not aware that in 28 states employer-provided insurance already must include birth control?  And that religious-affiliated organizations such as colleges and hospitals have been following these laws for years?  This is a controversy ginned up as one more weapon in the fight to get rid of Obama by any means--and any lie--possible.
They are desperate to change the subject.
And despite Mr. Bruni's contention, support for universal access to birth control is NOT going to be a major black mark on Obama in the general election, not when 98% of Catholics use birth control.

I have to disagree that Mr. Obama picked a foolish fight over birth control to be covered by all insurers. It's foolish that a Catholic business insurers will cover Viagra but not birth control. The Bible has no prohibition against contraceptives. Expecting women to be baby machines was just something made up by men in the Catholic Church. Why is the church having screaming fits over insurance and contraceptives when the best they could do when priests were raping little boys was transfer the sexual predators to other churchs so they could start over with a new set of boys? I have a hard time believing all those bishops are that offended by contraceptives while protecting rapists.

For Rich Daniels:

I speak of pragmatism in the ordinary use of the word. I was referencing Oliver Wendell Holmes famous "The Common Law" which if the field of Jurisprudence is known as Legal Realism. "The life of the law is experience." or some such thing. CL is based on common sense, i.e. pragmatism in the ordinary use of the word, Basically, law has to work. Ideology isn't practical. Exhibit 1: Prohibition. It didn't work - the prohibition of an evil gave birth to an even greater evil, and so the prohibition proved to be impractical. This kind of thing went on for hundreds of years. Eventually it became fundamental to all Anglo-Saxon civics. "If Hitler had invaded Hell, I should at least make a positive reference to the devil in the house of commons." - W. Churchill. That sort of thing.
